item.title: Live Updates: NATO Chief Vows Unity at Celebration, Despite Tensions
item.description: The prelude to the gathering of alliance country leaders was punctuated by testy exchanges between President Emmanuel Macron of France and President Trump.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Jens Stoltenberg, the NATO secretary general of NATO, on Wednesday called the grouping “the most effective alliance in history.”

item.title: For Trump and Europe, a Surprising Role Reversal
item.description: Where the president once kept European leaders off balance, Europe’s shifting landscape now has the Great Disrupter scrambling to recalibrate his approach.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump met with President Emmanuel Macron of France in London on Tuesday.

item.title: In Video, World Leaders Seem to Be Commiserating About Trump
item.description: The leaders of Canada, France and Britain did not appear to realize that their conversation at a Buckingham Palace reception was being recorded.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni

item.title: Australia Revokes Medical Evacuations for Offshore Detainees
item.description: The government called the policy, enacted just 10 months ago, a “back door” to let refugees into the country. Human rights advocates denounced the repeal as shameful.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A July rally in Sydney, Australia, calling for humane treatment of asylum seekers and refugees.

item.title: Kim Jong-un Visits Sacred Mountain on Horseback. Analysts Watch His Next Move.
item.description: The North Korean leader has often visited Mount Paektu, near the border with China, before making major policy shifts.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Italians Celebrate Their Coffee and Want the World to Do So, Too
item.description: Italy wants traditional Italian espresso to be inscribed on UNESCO’s list of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: A waiter serving espresso coffees at a bar in Milan.

item.title: Cha In-ha Becomes Third Young Korean Entertainer to Die in Two Months
item.description: The 27-year-old actor appears in a TV series that premiered just last week.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:description: Cha In-ha at an event for the show “Love With Flaws” in Seoul, South Korea, in August.

item.title: Typhoon Kammuri Kills at Least 17 as It Powers Through Philippines
item.description: Manila’s airport was shut for 12 hours and half a million people were evacuated as the typhoon swept through the archipelago.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay

item.title: Impeachment, Emmanuel Macron, Google: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Climate Change Is Accelerating: ‘Things Are Getting Worse’
item.description: The acceleration climate change's effects have brought the world “dangerously close” to abrupt and irreversible changes, scientists warned.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A whirlwind of hot ash and embers tore through the Cave Fire in Santa Barbara, Calif., last month.

item.title: America’s Dark History of Killing Its Own Troops With Cluster Munitions
item.description: The weapons are notorious for their effects on civilians. But five years of reporting and hundreds of interviews have revealed they’ve also killed and wounded scores of Americans.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: First Lt. Des Walton salutes during a memorial service for seven members of his company who were killed in an explosion at As Salman Airfield in Iraq. Walton was injured in that same explosion, and was recovering from his wounds at the time.

item.title: Donald Trump, China, James Bond: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: San Diego Man on List of Most Wanted Terrorists Faces New Charges
item.description: Jehad Serwan Mostafa, who the authorities say joined Al Shabab in his 20s, is believed to be the “highest-ranking U.S. citizen fighting overseas with a terrorist organization.”
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:description: Robert Brewer, the United States attorney in San Diego, announced new charges against Jehad Serwan Mostafa at a news conference on Monday.

item.title: Cha In-ha Becomes Third Young Korean Entertainer to Die in Two Months
item.description: The 27-year-old actor appears in a TV series that premiered just last week.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:description: Cha In-ha at an event for the show “Love With Flaws” in Seoul, South Korea, in August.

item.title: The Turner Prize Goes to … All 4 Shortlisted Artists
item.description: The artists, who included Oscar Murillo, asked to be considered as a group to make a statement on political unity. The judges agreed.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Uighurs, China Trade, NATO: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: North Korea Touts New Resort, Seeking to Blunt U.N. Sanctions
item.description: Tourism is one of the few remaining sources of hard currency for Kim Jong-un’s government. He has embarked on a push for more foreign visitors.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun

item.title: ‘I Don’t Know Prince Andrew,’ Trump Says. Photos Say Otherwise.
item.description: Speaking to reporters in London, President Trump denied knowing Prince Andrew, despite having been photographed with him on several occasions.
item.dc:creator: Iliana Magra
item.media:description: President Trump, Melania Trump and Prince Andrew, left, during a tour of Westminster Abbey in London in June.

item.title: Why Are These Foxes Tame? Maybe They Weren’t So Wild to Begin With
item.description: In a famous experiment, scientists bred Russian foxes without a fear of people. But the foxes’ ancestry raises new questions about when they became tame and what counts as domestication.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.media:description: Domesticated foxes in an enclosure at the Institute of Cytology and Genetics in Novosibirsk, Russia.

item.title: Trump Warns Trade Talks With China May Last Past 2020 Election
item.description: The president said he was in no rush to complete a deal, injecting further uncertainty into a dispute that has rocked global markets.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers, Keith Bradsher and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Edmund D. Fountain for The New York Times
item.media:description: The port of New Orleans. President Trump’s comments on Tuesday cast more uncertainty on an agreement he said he had made with China’s top trade envoy just weeks ago.

item.title: Tariffs, NATO, Philippines: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Ukraine Knew of Aid Freeze in July, Says Ex-Top Official in Kyiv
item.description: Ukraine’s government learned of the military aid freeze during the Trump administration’s pressure campaign — and tried to keep that knowledge from going public, an ex-deputy foreign minister said.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Olena Zerkal, a former deputy minister of foreign affairs of Ukraine, says she and other senior government officials knew in July of a freeze on American military aid.

item.title: ‘It Just Isn’t Working’: PISA Test Scores Cast Doubt on U.S. Education Efforts
item.description: An international exam shows that American 15-year-olds are stagnant in reading and math even though the country has spent billions to close gaps with the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein
item.media:description: The achievement gap in reading between high and low performers in the United States is widening.

item.title: Looking for a Castle or Country Home? Try Scotland
item.description: A 563-acre estate, complete with a new 12,000-square foot house, is being offered for $3.4 million.
item.dc:creator: Jon Hurdle

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Boris Johnson, NATO, China
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Second Australian Rescued After Nearly 2 Weeks in Outback; Other Feared Dead
item.description: The man, Phu Tran, was found by a livestock farmer south of Alice Springs in central Australia. Officials say they may have found the remains of the third member of their party.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A minibus traveling along an isolated road in central Australia last August. The region is known for its remoteness.

item.title: Prince Andrew’s Accuser Takes Her Case to the BBC
item.description: For the first time, Virginia Roberts Giuffre told a British television audience about a trip she took to London in 2001, during which, she says, she was ordered to have sex with Prince Andrew.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Virginia Roberts Giuffre during an interview with the BBC on Monday.

item.title: In Russia, an Updated Law With New Restrictions on Freedom of Speech
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday signed a law that could require anyone distributing information and being paid from abroad to register as a foreign agent.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A rally demanding internet freedom in Moscow in April last year.

item.title: Airstrike and Artillery Shelling Kill Civilians in Syrian Towns
item.description: Thirteen civilians were killed in a strike on a market in a rebel-held town and eight children were among those killed by shelling near a school in a Kurdish town.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.category: White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)
item.media:description: Members of the Syrian Civil Defense recover a body from the aftermath of an air strike in the town of Maaret al-Numan in Syria on Monday.

item.title: Was This 18,000-Year-Old Siberian Puppy a Dog or a Wolf?
item.description: The animal was buried in a lump of frozen mud in Russia, its fur, whiskers and body fully intact. Scientists are studying its DNA to understand whether it is a dog or a wolf.
item.dc:creator: Laura M. Holson
item.media:credit: Sergei Fyodorov/The Yakutsk Mammoth Museum, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Scientists presented a unique prehistoric canine, believed to be 18,000 years old, to the public on Monday. It was found in permafrost in the far east of Russia.

item.title: For Boris Johnson, a Perilous Week Negotiating Terrorism and Trump
item.description: President Trump has roiled British politics before, with comments on terrorism, as well as Brexit, trade and other sensitive issues. He may do so again as he visits for a NATO meeting.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Jeff Overs/BBC/Agence France-Presse, via Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, right, during a segment of BBC’s political program “The Andrew Marr Show” on Sunday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Hong Kong, Huawei, opioid crisis: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Lauryn Ishak for The New York Times

item.title: Dead Whale, 220 Pounds of Debris Inside, Is a ‘Grim Reminder’ of Ocean Trash
item.description: The sperm whale washed up on a Scottish beach with a stomach full of rope, netting and plastic. “What was unusual in this case was the sheer volume,” a local expert said.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: The 10-year-old whale died after becoming stranded on a sand bank, according to a local research group, the Scottish Marine Animal Stranding Scheme.

item.title: Fighting Extradition, Huawei Executive Writes of ‘Moments of Fear’
item.description: On the first anniversary of her arrest, Meng Wanzhou wrote a public letter describing her life in Vancouver, where she is living in a seven-bedroom mansion.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Meng Wanzhou, Huawei’s chief financial officer, near her Vancouver home in October.

item.title: Activist’s Case Hints at What Changes and What Stays the Same in Cuba
item.description: José Daniel Ferrer’s arrest reflects the lengths to which the Díaz-Canel government will go against dissidents.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: José Daniel Ferrer Garcia speaking with reporters in 2016.

item.title: London Bridge Attack Victims Were Advocates for Prisoner Rehabilitation
item.description: Saskia Jones and Jack Merritt, who were killed in the attack, had worked with a prison education program backed by Cambridge University.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Flowers left for Jack Merritt and Saskia Jones in London on Monday near the site where they were killed in what the police called a terrorism-related attack.

item.title: China Hits Back at U.S. Over Hong Kong Bill in a Mostly Symbolic Move
item.description: Beijing said it would suspend visits to Hong Kong by American warships and impose sanctions on several nongovernmental groups. The measures suggest China is wary of upsetting trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Hong Kong, above, on Thursday celebrated President Trump’s signing of legislation aimed at curbing human-rights abuses in the city.

item.title: Democrats, Prince Charles, N.F.L.: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: ‘Incredible Story of Survival’: Woman Rescued After 12 Days in Outback
item.description: Tire tracks and a note helped lead to a water hole where an Australian survived by boiling water. But two other people are still missing.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: NATO Readies a 70th Birthday Party, With Low-Key Celebrations
item.description: A short meeting of the alliance’s leaders in London is meant to avoid conflict, but there are worries about the intentions of Presidents Trump and Emmanuel Macron.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: NATO leaders during the 2018 summit meeting in Brussels.

item.title: ISIS Is Losing Afghan Territory. That Means Little for Its Victims.
item.description: Offensives against the Islamic State’s Afghan branch have brought it down to several hundred fighters, officials say. But they warn that the group’s cruelty is still a threat.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Mujib Mashal
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Manila Airport Shut as Typhoon Kammuri Hits the Philippines
item.description: Kammuri has begun dumping torrential rains across the eastern provinces of the archipelago and could disrupt the Southeast Asian Games.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Malta, Prince Andrew, Northern Ireland
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: At Least 14 People Killed in Burkina Faso Church Attack
item.description: The country was once a pocket of calm in West Africa, but the past year’s violence has killed hundreds and forced nearly a million people from their homes.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Malta Leader Says He Will Resign, as Murder Inquiry Widens
item.description: An investigation into the 2017 murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia has reached into the government, triggering protests and a promise by Prime Minister Joseph Muscat to quit next year.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Joseph Muscat of Malta addressing the nation during a TV broadcast on Sunday.

item.title: Suspects in Mormon Family’s Killing Are Arrested in Mexico
item.description: The announcement did not include details on the suspects’ identities or their connection to the murders. The López Obrador administration is under pressure to curb spiraling violence.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Semple
item.media:description: Members of the LeBarón family, part of the Mormon community that saw nine of its members murdered, participate in a march against violence to mark President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s first year in office.

item.title: As Troubles Grow, Mexicans Keep the Faith With Their President
item.description: One year into his term, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador faces a stagnant economy and spiraling violence, but Mexicans still place their hopes in him.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Malkin
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador on Mexico waving next to his wife, Beatriz Gutierrez Muller, during a rally marking his first year in office in Mexico City, Sunday.

item.title: Hong Kong, Fentanyl in China, Julian Assange: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: With Brutal Crackdown, Iran Is Convulsed by Worst Unrest in 40 Years
item.description: What started as a protest over a surprise increase in gasoline prices turned into widespread demonstrations met with a systematic repression that left at least 180 people dead.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Rick Gladstone
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Irish Ex-Soldier Who Married ISIS Fighter Is Arrested
item.description: Lisa Smith, 38, and her 2-year-old daughter were deported by Turkey from a Syrian displacement camp and landed in Dublin on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Lisa Smith, with a pink blanket over her head, leaving a Turkish Airlines plane at Dublin Airport.

item.title: China Is Aiming to ‘Break’ Detained Australian Writer, Lawyers Say
item.description: Yang Hengjun has been shackled, cut off from all contact with his family and interrogated daily to make him confess to being a spy, his representatives said.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Yang Hengjun with his wife, Yuan Xiaoliang. He was detained in January on a trip to China.

item.title: In Prince Andrew Scandal, Prince Charles Emerges as Monarch-in-Waiting
item.description: After a public-relations debacle stirred questions about the role of Queen Elizabeth II, the Prince of Wales is asserting a newfound authority in British royal affairs.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Charles at the state opening of Parliament in London in October.

item.title: U.S. Drone Killed Afghan Civilians, Officials Say
item.description: The strike on a car killed all five onboard, including a woman who had given birth hours before, relatives and officials said.
item.dc:creator: Farooq Jan Mangal and Fahim Abed

item.title: Assange to Testify on Being Recorded in Embassy in London
item.description: Recordings have emerged of private conversations that Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, had while living in the Ecuadorean Embassy. He and a Spanish prosecutor blame the United States.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Julian Assange addressing members of the news media from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in 2017.

item.title: ‘I Wanted to Die:’ Northern Ireland Confronts a Suicide Crisis
item.description: Haunted by a violent past, the territory has one of the highest suicide rates in the world.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joe Holbeach, 69, links his suicidal behaviors to the suffering he experienced during the Northern Ireland conflict.

item.title: Hong Kong Police Fire Tear Gas as Protesters Return in Force
item.description: After a week of relative calm and a vote that boosted protesters’ cause, officers fired tear gas and rubber bullets, and demonstrators attacked shops.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Yu
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of people took part in a pro-democracy protest in the Tsim Sha Tsui neighborhood of Hong Kong on Sunday.

item.title: Leonardo DiCaprio Responds to Brazil’s President About Amazon Fires
item.description: The actor and environmentalist released a statement on Saturday after President Jair Bolsonaro falsely accused him of funding the fires recently set in the Amazon rainforest.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Theo Wargo/Getty Images For Global Citizen
item.media:description: “At this time of crisis for the Amazon, I support the people of Brazil working to save their natural and cultural heritage,” Leonardo DiCaprio posted on Instagram on Saturday.
